title: Graph on Interval
content:
A graph on {1,...,n} is represented as a `SimpleGraph (Fin n)`.

Using `Fin n` ensures vertices are exactly 0, 1, ..., n-1 (which we interpret as 1, ..., n).

title: Independent Triple
content:
Three vertices a, b, c form an **independent set** if no two are adjacent:

¬G.Adj a b ∧ ¬G.Adj b c ∧ ¬G.Adj a c

This is the key property we want to find for additive triples.

title: Triangle-Free Graph
content:
A graph is **triangle-free** if it contains no three mutually adjacent vertices:

∀ a b c, ¬(G.Adj a b ∧ G.Adj b c ∧ G.Adj a c)

Triangle-free graphs have structural constraints that force large independent sets.
mathContext: By Ramsey theory (R(3,3)=6), every 2-coloring of K₆ has a monochromatic triangle, so triangle-free graphs have independence number ≥ √n.

title: Additive Triple
content:
An **additive triple** is (a, b, c) where a + b = c and a, b > 0.

These are also called **Schur triples** in the context of Ramsey theory. The constraint a, b > 0 ensures non-degeneracy.

title: Has Independent Additive Triple
content:
The key predicate: does G contain vertices a, b, a+b that are pairwise non-adjacent?

This combines:
- Additive structure: a + b = c
- Graph structure: no edges between a, b, c

The problem asks: is this always satisfiable for triangle-free G on large n?

title: Erdős Problem #895
content:
**The Conjecture:**

There exists N such that for all n ≥ N, every triangle-free graph on {1,...,n} has an independent additive triple.

The question is: does such N exist, and what is its value?

title: The Threshold
content:
The threshold is **n = 18**.

For n ≥ 18, every triangle-free graph has an independent additive triple. For n = 17, a counterexample exists.

title: Barber's Theorem
content:
**Ben Barber's Result:**

For all n ≥ 18, every triangle-free graph on {1,...,n} has an independent additive triple a, b, a+b.

This was verified computationally using a SAT solver, not proved by hand.
mathContext: SAT solvers encode the combinatorial problem as Boolean satisfiability and prove unsatisfiability of the negation for each n ≥ 18.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #895: SOLVED**

The conjecture is TRUE with threshold N = 18. We prove this by applying Barber's theorem.

title: Counterexample for n = 17
content:
**Sharpness:**

There exists a triangle-free graph on {1,...,17} with NO independent additive triple.

This shows the threshold 18 is optimal.

title: Ramsey R(3,3) = 6
content:
**Classical Ramsey Theory:**

Any 2-coloring of K₆ (complete graph on 6 vertices) contains a monochromatic triangle.

Equivalently: every graph on ≥ 6 vertices has either a triangle or an independent set of size 3.

title: Independence Bound
content:
**Ramsey Lower Bound:**

Every triangle-free graph on n vertices has an independent set of size ≥ √n.

This follows from R(3,k) ≤ Ck²/log k, giving large independent sets.

title: Sum-Free Sets
content:
A set S is **sum-free** if it contains no Schur triple:

∀ a, b ∈ S, a + b ∉ S

Sum-free sets avoid additive structure. The problem relates to finding sets that are NOT sum-free within independent sets.

title: Schur Numbers
content:
The **Schur number S(k)** is the largest n such that {1,...,n} can be k-colored with no monochromatic Schur triple.

- S(1) = 1
- S(2) = 4
- S(3) = 13
- S(4) = 44
- S(5) = 160 (known since 2017)

title: Hindman Sets
Hajnal's Conjecture
content:
**Open Generalization:**

Hajnal conjectured that for large n, every triangle-free graph on {1,...,n} has an independent Hindman set—all finite sums of some base set form an independent set.

This is stronger than Erdős 895 (which only requires a, b, a+b).

title: Hajnal's Conjecture is OPEN
content:
The reflexive statement `hajnalConjecture ↔ hajnalConjecture` marks this as an open problem.

The generalization from triples to full Hindman sets remains unresolved.

title: Mantel's Theorem
content:
**Edge Bound for Triangle-Free Graphs:**

A triangle-free graph on n vertices has at most n²/4 edges.

This is achieved by the complete bipartite graph K_{n/2, n/2}. It constrains how 'dense' triangle-free graphs can be.

title: Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #895: SOLVED**

- Answer: YES, independent additive triples exist for n ≥ 18
- Method: SAT solver verification by Ben Barber
- Threshold: n = 18 is sharp (counterexample for n = 17)
- Open: Hajnal's generalization to Hindman sets
